qas.question: When was the Unicode Standard first published?
When was the latest version, Unicode 8.0, released?
What was the last major version of Unicode to be published in book form?
What year was it announced that only the core specification for Unicode would be printed in physical form?
What does the print on demand, core version not include?

answers.text: any code charts or standard annexes

qas.question: What month did the Consortium first publish Unicode?
When was it announced that Unicode would no longer be available in book form?
How many pages was the original Unicode standard?
What extra sections are not included on the Unicode website?

context: The Consortium first published The Unicode Standard (ISBN 0-321-18578-1) in <a0_0><b5_0>1991<b5_0/><a0_0/> and continues to develop standards based on that original work. The latest version of the standard, Unicode 8.0, was released in <a1_0><b6_0>June<b6_0/> 2015<a1_0/> and is available from the consortium's website. The last of the major versions (versions x.0) to be published in book form was <a2_0>Unicode 5.0<a2_0/> (ISBN 0-321-48091-0), but since Unicode 6.0 the full text of the standard is no longer being published in book form. In <a3_0><b7_0>2012<b7_0/><a3_0/>, however, it was announced that only the core specification for Unicode version 6.1 would be made available as a <b8_0>692<b8_0/>-page print-on-demand paperback. Unlike the previous major version printings of the Standard, the print-on-demand core specification does not include <a4_0>any <b9_0>code charts or standard annexes<b9_0/><a4_0/>, but the entire standard, including the core specification, will still remain freely available on the Unicode website.
